title: How to Make Your Own Cardboard Box Closet Organizer

steps.headline: Save 2 to 4 cereal boxes, or the equivalent in other thin cardboard material.
steps.description: Cut the front and back sides out and lay them flat on your workspace in a row.

steps.headline: Choose some scrapbooking or wrapping paper in a pretty pattern.
steps.description: Your closet dividers can be an expression of your personal style and match your home décor.

steps.headline: Spray a layer of spray glue over outside of the cereal box.
steps.description: Place a piece of scrapbook or wrapping paper directly on top of the glue and smooth it out.

steps.headline: Allow the glue to dry according to package directions.
steps.description: Repeat with as many box sides as you plan to use.

steps.headline: Flip the cardboard over so that the plain cardboard back is showing.
steps.description: Find a round, plastic container lid, such as 1 that comes on top of a cocoa, ovaltine or baby formula cardboard container. You will use this to trace your divider shape. You can also draw a large oblong shape freehand; however, the lid helps you to ensure all of the dividers are the same, large size.

steps.headline: Place the container lid on top of the cardboard and trace 2 connecting circles onto the cardboard.
steps.description: Trace 1 circle and then trace another 1 just beside it, to create an oblong shape. Where the circles connect, it should form a straight line.

steps.headline: Cut the shape out of the cardboard.
steps.description: Repeat the process 4 times on each side of a cereal box, until you have enough dividers for all the types of clothing hanging in your closet.

steps.headline: Trace a small round shape, about the size of a large milk cap or juice cap at the top of the round dividers.
steps.description: Make sure the cap is slightly larger than the bar on which your clothing hangs.

steps.headline: Cut a sharp angle from the bottom side of the divider up toward the small circle.
steps.description: Cut the small circle out at the top of your dividers. The cut upward will allow you to insert the divider onto the clothing bar. If you cut from the top down to the circle, your divider will not stay on your closet bar.

steps.headline: Write the names of the types of clothing onto your dividers using permanent marker.
steps.description: Hang them on your closet bar and divide your clothing accordingly.

steps.headline: Save thick cardboard boxes.
steps.description: The best time of year to find them is around Christmas, when you are receiving presents and ordering things by mail. Choose 5 to 10 boxes that are of similar size and shape.

steps.headline: Measure the length from the floor of the closet to the closet rod.
steps.description: Lay your boxes on a table with the openings toward you and measure how long they are. You want to use enough boxes so that it is approximately the same measurement or slightly smaller.

steps.headline: Cut off the flaps of all of your boxes with sharp scissors or a box cutter.
steps.description: Take them all outside and spray paint the inside of the boxes and the sides with the paint color of your choice. Leave them in a well-aired place while they dry according to the can's instructions.

steps.headline: Lay your boxes side by side on a long table, with the openings facing toward you.
steps.description: Measure the length and width of the side.

steps.headline: Measure and cut 2 pieces of fabric that are the length of the side and 1 that is the length and width of the back.
steps.description: This is the material you will use to cover the cardboard. You can also use drawer lining or wallpaper.

steps.headline: Turn all of your boxes so that the same side is facing toward you.
steps.description: Spray the side with strong spray adhesive or paint fabric glue on it. Place the fabric strip on top of the boxes, making sure the boxes align right next to each other.

steps.headline: Allow the glue to dry completely, and then carefully turn the boxes toward the back.
steps.description: Use the spray adhesive again and then align the back piece. Allow it to dry and then repeat on the remaining side.

steps.headline: Cut 2 small slits in the top of the top box in your organizer; 1 near the rear and another near the front.
steps.description: Put a length of rope through the back slit and knot well in the inside of the box.

steps.headline: Place the organizer in your closet.
steps.description: You may choose to put it at a side or in the center. Make sure the bottom box rests on the floor.

steps.headline: Loop the rope over the top of the closet rod, and bring it through the front slit.
steps.description: Knot the rope and cut off any excess. Although the fabric will hold your boxes together, the rope will keep it from moving or falling when weighted down with clothes.

steps.headline: Place a different type of clothing in each cardboard box.
steps.description: You can organize everything from sweaters to scarves to socks.

tyn: Plastic juice or milk carton lid
text: Cardboard Closet Dividers Save 2 to 4 cereal boxes, or the equivalent in other thin cardboard material. Cut the front and back sides out and lay them flat on your workspace in a row. Choose some scrapbooking or wrapping paper in a pretty pattern. Your closet dividers can be an expression of your personal style and match your home décor. Spray a layer of spray glue over outside of the cereal box. Place a piece of scrapbook or wrapping paper directly on top of the glue and smooth it out. Allow the glue to dry according to package directions. Repeat with as many box sides as you plan to use. Flip the cardboard over so that the plain cardboard back is showing. Find a round, plastic container lid, such as 1 that comes on top of a cocoa, ovaltine or baby formula cardboard container. You will use this to trace your divider shape. You can also draw a large oblong shape freehand; however, the lid helps you to ensure all of the dividers are the same, large size. Place the container lid on top of the cardboard and trace 2 connecting circles onto the cardboard. Trace 1 circle and then trace another 1 just beside it, to create an oblong shape. Where the circles connect, it should form a straight line. Cut the shape out of the cardboard. Repeat the process 4 times on each side of a cereal box, until you have enough dividers for all the types of clothing hanging in your closet. Trace a small round shape, about the size of a large milk cap or juice cap at the top of the round dividers. Make sure the cap is slightly larger than the bar on which your clothing hangs. Cut a sharp angle from the bottom side of the divider up toward the small circle. Cut the small circle out at the top of your dividers. The cut upward will allow you to insert the divider onto the clothing bar. If you cut from the top down to the circle, your divider will not stay on your closet bar. Write the names of the types of clothing onto your dividers using permanent marker. Hang them on your closet bar and divide your clothing accordingly. Hanging Closet Organizer Save thick cardboard boxes. The best time of year to find them is around Christmas, when you are receiving presents and ordering things by mail. Choose 5 to 10 boxes that are of similar size and shape. Measure the length from the floor of the closet to the closet rod. Lay your boxes on a table with the openings toward you and measure how long they are. You want to use enough boxes so that it is approximately the same measurement or slightly smaller. Cut off the flaps of all of your boxes with sharp scissors or a box cutter. Take them all outside and spray paint the inside of the boxes and the sides with the paint color of your choice. Leave them in a well-aired place while they dry according to the can's instructions. Lay your boxes side by side on a long table, with the openings facing toward you. Measure the length and width of the side. Measure and cut 2 pieces of fabric that are the length of the side and 1 that is the length and width of the back. This is the material you will use to cover the cardboard. You can also use drawer lining or wallpaper. Turn all of your boxes so that the same side is facing toward you. Spray the side with strong spray adhesive or paint fabric glue on it. Place the fabric strip on top of the boxes, making sure the boxes align right next to each other. Allow the glue to dry completely, and then carefully turn the boxes toward the back. Use the spray adhesive again and then align the back piece. Allow it to dry and then repeat on the remaining side. Cut 2 small slits in the top of the top box in your organizer; 1 near the rear and another near the front. Put a length of rope through the back slit and knot well in the inside of the box. Place the organizer in your closet. You may choose to put it at a side or in the center. Make sure the bottom box rests on the floor. Loop the rope over the top of the closet rod, and bring it through the front slit. Knot the rope and cut off any excess. Although the fabric will hold your boxes together, the rope will keep it from moving or falling when weighted down with clothes. Place a different type of clothing in each cardboard box. You can organize everything from sweaters to scarves to socks.
sentences: Cardboard Closet Dividers Save 2 to 4 cereal boxes, or the equivalent in other thin cardboard material.
Cut the front and back sides out and lay them flat on your workspace in a row.
Choose some scrapbooking or wrapping paper in a pretty pattern.
Your closet dividers can be an expression of your personal style and match your home décor.
Spray a layer of spray glue over outside of the cereal box.
Place a piece of scrapbook or wrapping paper directly on top of the glue and smooth it out.
Allow the glue to dry according to package directions.
Repeat with as many box sides as you plan to use.
Flip the cardboard over so that the plain cardboard back is showing.
Find a round, plastic container lid, such as 1 that comes on top of a cocoa, ovaltine or baby formula cardboard container.
You will use this to trace your divider shape.
You can also draw a large oblong shape freehand; however, the lid helps you to ensure all of the dividers are the same, large size.
Place the container lid on top of the cardboard and trace 2 connecting circles onto the cardboard.
Trace 1 circle and then trace another 1 just beside it, to create an oblong shape.
Where the circles connect, it should form a straight line.
Cut the shape out of the cardboard.
Repeat the process 4 times on each side of a cereal box, until you have enough dividers for all the types of clothing hanging in your closet.
Trace a small round shape, about the size of a large milk cap or juice cap at the top of the round dividers.
Make sure the cap is slightly larger than the bar on which your clothing hangs.
Cut a sharp angle from the bottom side of the divider up toward the small circle.
Cut the small circle out at the top of your dividers.
The cut upward will allow you to insert the divider onto the clothing bar.
If you cut from the top down to the circle, your divider will not stay on your closet bar.
Write the names of the types of clothing onto your dividers using permanent marker.
Hang them on your closet bar and divide your clothing accordingly.
Hanging Closet Organizer Save thick cardboard boxes.
The best time of year to find them is around Christmas, when you are receiving presents and ordering things by mail.
Choose 5 to 10 boxes that are of similar size and shape.
Measure the length from the floor of the closet to the closet rod.
Lay your boxes on a table with the openings toward you and measure how long they are.
You want to use enough boxes so that it is approximately the same measurement or slightly smaller.
Cut off the flaps of all of your boxes with sharp scissors or a box cutter.
Take them all outside and spray paint the inside of the boxes and the sides with the paint color of your choice.
Leave them in a well-aired place while they dry according to the can's instructions.
Lay your boxes side by side on a long table, with the openings facing toward you.
Measure the length and width of the side.
Measure and cut 2 pieces of fabric that are the length of the side and 1 that is the length and width of the back.
This is the material you will use to cover the cardboard.
You can also use drawer lining or wallpaper.
Turn all of your boxes so that the same side is facing toward you.
Spray the side with strong spray adhesive or paint fabric glue on it.
Place the fabric strip on top of the boxes, making sure the boxes align right next to each other.
Allow the glue to dry completely, and then carefully turn the boxes toward the back.
Use the spray adhesive again and then align the back piece.
Allow it to dry and then repeat on the remaining side.
Cut 2 small slits in the top of the top box in your organizer; 1 near the rear and another near the front.
Put a length of rope through the back slit and knot well in the inside of the box.
Place the organizer in your closet.
You may choose to put it at a side or in the center.
Make sure the bottom box rests on the floor.
Loop the rope over the top of the closet rod, and bring it through the front slit.
Knot the rope and cut off any excess.
Although the fabric will hold your boxes together, the rope will keep it from moving or falling when weighted down with clothes.
Place a different type of clothing in each cardboard box.
You can organize everything from sweaters to scarves to socks.
